projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2008-01 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2011-05 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

cell.l: SHall I Invent Diſtinctions to Conform,
When Perſecutors Threaten with a Storm?
No: Spread their Threats before the Lord and ſay,
Grant Boldneſs to thy Servants in thy way.
Shall I Recant, and wheel about, and turn,
That I may my Unworthy Right-hand burn.
No: For ſo doing thou art Self-Condemn'd,
Juſtly Exploded things none may Commend.
Shall I Deny my Lord, in Hope that I
May go with Peter, and weep bitterly?
No: Thoſe that will not hear when he doth Call,
He will deride, when Fear ſhall on them fall;
Shall I in my Reſerved Sence Subſcribe,
And ſeek to Choak my Conſcience with a B • ibe?
No: Senſe Reſerv'd Saphira Caus'd to dye,
The love of Money bringeth Miſery
Shall I to feed a Carkaſs that muſt dye,
Nouriſh a Worm unto Eternity?
No: Live by Faith, and on Chriſts Body feed,
And from this Gnawing Worm, thou ſhalt be freed
Shall I the Fury of a Man to ſhun,
Under the Terours of Jehovah run?
No: God ſtill liveth, ſhun his Dreadful hand;
But man muſt yield to Death at his Command.
Shall I to ſave a Skin leap into Hell,
And there with Everlaſting Burnings dwell?
No: Hell's a diſmal dreadful, doleful place,
Spare not thy Skin to ſave thee in this Caſe.
Shall I leave Gods Path, for the Common Way,
And venture with a Multitude to Stray?
No: Few there be that find the Gate of Life,
To enter in with them let be thy Strife.
Shall I for fear of Singularity.
Deſtroy the Apple of a ſingle Eye?
No: To be ſingular in Vertue is,
No Cauſe of Shame, but Cauſe of Joy and Bliſs.
Shall I inſtead of the Transformity
Take my Lords Bill, and write Conformity?
No: He that made thee Steward will Regard,
Thy Faith, or Faithlesneſs in thy Reward.
Shall I now into Queſtion call his [NOT]
Preſuming to Correct it with a Blot?
No: For he will on thee his Plagues Inflict,
If thou preſume his Sence to Contradict.
Shall I bow down unto the Father of lyes
That through his Bounty I may come to riſe?
No: Were there Twenty Six ſuch Fathers known,
Not one of all their Beneficies own.
Shall I be Super Superſtitious
Becauſe the Elders and he Scribes are thus?
No: Great Men are not always wiſe: and men,
Of Worldly Learning do Chriſts Croſs Contemn.
Shall I be taken with the Golden Cup
And Sip with her with whom I dare not Sup
No: If her out ſide thee to her Allure,
Share of her Puniſhments thou muſt Endure.
Shall I comply for Pulpit Liberty,
And make Gods Truth Beholding to my Lye?
No, God from Pulpits now ſmall Honour hath,
None can come there that walk in Vertues Path.
Shall I from God ſhrink, fearing of a Jayl
As if Jeh • vah did hi • Pris'ners fail?
No: Some who did before a Priſon fear,
Received Courage, after they came there
Shall I? when God ſays Preach, and men ſay nay;
Take Time to ſtudy whether to Obey?
No; Preach God's Word, both in, and out of ſeaſon:
Pray him to ſhield thee from men void of reaſon.
Shall I make baulks of good Land in this Nation.
And tempt God to [HIS] Act of Tranſportation?
No; better men ſhould baniſh thee, than God;
Who will in time take from thy back their rod.
Shall I the perils of my Duty Count.
And forget Gods Appearing in the Mount?
No; view thine aid, thy company, the prize,
And thou thereby all danger will deſpiſe.
Shall I leaſt: Wife and Children be undone,
Go from Gods Bleſſing into the warm Sun:
No; If their love, thy Chriſtian Love devour;
Chriſt will not own thee, when he comes in Power.
Shall I Adore, and ſhall I not profeſs,
Shall Danger make my Duty to ſeem leſss?
No; if for ſhame, thou wilt not ſpeak his praiſe,
For ſhame he will not thee to Glory raiſe.
Shall I expect Salvation by Chriſts Croſs
And ſhall I not for him count all things loſs?
No: all things muſt be loſs, if thou wouldſt have,
The vertue of his Croſs thy Soul to ſave.
Shall I truſt a deceitful Heart? When I Both ſee,
and cannot ſee its Treachery?
No; Truſt it not, Correct it, keep it ſtrait,
Leaſt thou forſake thy God, through its deceit.
Shall I not fear, when I ſee others fall;
Leaſt my fall be the next and worſt of All?
No; Wiſe Man, but by others loſs Fore-Warn'd,
Will ſtrive, that he may keep himſelf Unharm'd.
Shall I not ſtand, Although to ſtand unable?
Becauſe JEHOVAH and his Word is ſtable.
No; Needful Aid, will God deny to thoſe,
Who Truſt and Confidence in him Repoſe.
Shall I, even I, depart from Chriſt his Church,
And Hireling like, now leave them in the lurch?
No: From that Faithful Shepherd, Pattern take,
Who to preſerve his Sheep, dy'd for their Sake.
Shall I deſſert when Wolves break in upon them,
Or, ſhall I not contend that none may wrong them?
No; Feed the flock, from danger ſhelter them,
And they will prove thy Royal Diadem.
Shall I forget if little ones I offend,
Chriſt takes it ill, and I muſt ſmart 'th end?
No; Better thou ty'd to a great Mill-ſtone,
Into the Sea or Ocean thou wert thrown.
Shall I or S.C. A.B. at laſt come to Recant,
Becauſe the Judge and Biſhops do me haunt?
No; Beaſt nnd Dragon, do they what they will,
Be always Faithful, Conſtant, ſtedfaſt ſtill.
Shall I conform now in this latter Age,
When Anti-Chriſt is paſſing of his ſtage?
No; ſince the play's near done, ſcorn to appear,
Amongſt the Train, O'th Beaſt, or in his Geer

l.hi: Then am I full reſolved by God's Grace,
That to the Devil I will not give place.
God give thee Strength, thine Enemies deſtroy,
And make thee Fellow-feeler of his Joy.

lg.l: And let Gods Servants all, who on Earth dwell,
To theſe things ſay, Amen. And ſo Farewel
